text: We've been dealing with climate change issues for decades.  First it was global warming and when the earth's temperature went up it changed to not and relabled to climate change. One minute there's correlation between temperature and climate and then there's not the next.  Could it be that climate change is just a natural phenomenon? Afterall,  the earth's temperature has been warming since after the ice age  - as shown by the ever receding glaciers even before the industrial revolution. The notion that imposing radical green new deal restrictions on our country will solve the problem is misguided at best. Our carbon footprint has been decreasing with the new technology that enables  us to use our resources in a cleaner and efficient way. The world should focus on nations that are given a free pass to pollute unabated because of their "developing nations" status.

text: I love how PragerU, a youtube channel funded by the Wilks brothers, who own a massive fracking company, are trying to tell people  that climate change won't hurt us. Most of their points in the video are wrong anyways. Their claim that increased CO2 means increased plant food is very wrong. They're talking about how CO2 is a reactant in photosynthesis, but the problem is, CO2 isn't the limiting reactant, so even if there's more of it, it won't increase the photosynthesis rates. They use misleading numbers like .03% to .04% CO2 in the atmosphere which makes the change seem small. In reality though, that's a 33% increase in CO2 which is massive. Not to mention, that in turn also increases levels of water vapor, which is a much stronger greenhouse gas.

text: The theory you're talking about is called Carbon fertilizing, which does make the Earth a greener place, however that doesn't really mean anything. First, there are literally thousands of limiting factors that keep plants from continuously utilizing CO2 such as soil nitrogen levels and the seasonal fluctuation of CO2 uptake. Second, many studies have found that plant life acclimates to CO2 levels and photosynthesis slows down, meaning that proportionally they won't photosynthesis more if more CO2 is released. It's all about balance with CO2 levels; yes the earth will become greener and vegetation will increase with increased CO2 levels, but humans and animals will suffer.

text:
Individual action in reducing CO2 emissions is pointless. It makes no difference whatsoever. Collective action is the only effective way to change the climate. One aluminium smelter emits many life times of your CO2 emissions in a single day, so in this area the government has a place to act.
As for attacking people rather than their arguments, that fallacy is so common place and erroneous it has a name: Ad Hominem. If you truly believe the argument a person is using is wrong, don't name call the author, cite some evidence to refute their claims. And don't resort to magical thinking. Satan, Jehovah, Vishnu...   none of these fictional characters have any role to play in this very serious, existential debate.
Finally, making changes to the CO2 emissions of the human race today will not have any effect on the climate tomorrow. Nor the next year. Any reductions we make today are an attempt to mitigate the dire predictions that the real experts, those qualified and experienced in the domain and not ill-informed TV show pundits, tell us are on the way.

text:
@Mobius One  Well anthropogenic climate change has already been established. Even this video doesn't deny it. The question is the extent of the damage that might arise from an increase in CO2 concentrations. In such regards estimates vary, however usually climate scientists and activists follow a more robust approach as the consequences of inaction might be severe. The thing with nuclear energy is that it ticks all the boxes. It provides clean energy and could be considered more capitalist-friendly, which (by the way) I'm not against. Even if you were to doubt the science behind fossil fuels' role in climate change, you would have to agree that fossil fuel burning has caused, especially in areas where they are burnt more, severe respiratory health problems and cancers across demographics. If you were to argue that the energy generated by fossil fuels has overall in many cases increased the standard of living of individuals, you should still support nuclear over fossil fuel energy as it will further decrease the number of deaths caused by cancers whilst still keeping the standard of living at the same level. 
I think people on both sides need to be looking at this issue on a practical standpoint. Endlessly burning fossil fuels, in the long run, is not sustainable, whilst completely relying on wind and solar energy would decrease the overall standard of living. The thing is nobody has proposed legislation for increasing the degree of nuclear energy use, some movements on the left have largely given it a bad name whilst conservatives have not supported it either (rather relying on fossil fuels).

text:
@danieldjz  Well let's consider the contributors to global warming before and after humans.

Before:
Volcanic activity
El nino southern oscillation 
11-year solar cycle 

After: 
10 gigatonnes of Co2 produced annually
9 gigatonnes of methane produced annually
Rise in water vapor due to rising global temperatures
Massive deforestation
Volcanic activity
El Niño southern oscillation
11-year solar cycle

My point is, before humans it was much less emissions, and inconsistently produced by natural phenomena. So periods of high Co2 were offset by periods of very little. That is not the case today, greenhouse gas emissions are consistent and increasing nearly every year.

text:
The oceans serve as earth’s mobile reservoir (sink) for holding CO2.  When the earth heats up, the oceans release CO2.  So, it is the natural heating that has been occurring for 12,000 years that is creating more CO2.  
CO2 isn’t creating the heating.  CO2 is a lagging indicator, not a predictive (leading) one.  The CO2 concentration lags behind temperature by centuries in the glacial-interglacial cycles, so clearly CO2 does not cause temperatures to rise, temperatures cause CO2 to rise.  Even some liberal skeptics agree that a close examination of the CH4, CO2, and temperature fluctuations recorded in the Antarctic ice core records does in fact reveal that yes, the temperature moved first in what is a very tight correlation.
Most liberals have the cause and effect backwards.  Go figure.

text:
@Karat Kravat Thank you but I lecture at a British university on the topic so have no need to 'look this up' as have already done in depth research as well as working with some of the historic proxy data that's used to recreate past climate. Also teach statistics & aware of how a lot of this data is being fudged (that's a polite term for manipulated)! Personally always go back to the raw data, its enlightening. Yes, CO2 is a greenhouse gas but to suggest a trace gas, 0.03%  of the atmosphere drives climate is not supportable (it also lags behind temperature). What's being used to make predictions that's scaring the crap out of our young are simplistic models which for the past 20 years have given incredible over estimates of the actual (recorded) data. Better to look to man made chemicals like sulphur hexaflouride, a greater greenhouse component which no one is talking about. Personally not alarmed by CO2 levels but am concerned about use of plastics, pollution, species loss, habitat fragmentation, degradation & loss.
You might want to check out Lorenz on climate modelling. A mathematician turned meteorologists who produced the first computer climate simulations. The term 'butterfly effect' may ring a bell.
author: Veronica Edmonds-Brown

text: I will definitely check out Lorenz on climate modelling. Furthermore, as I see that you have an appreciation for raw data and science: Could you please state the sources for your claims?
author: Karat Kravat

text: @Karat Kravat  if you want to explore UK data  the  Radcliffe observatory Oxford have data sets going back to 1760s. Canadian & many US states also have long term data going back to the late 1890s.  IPPCs earlier reports are a good place start to compare how the data has been 'adjusted' over time even in their own reports. But you also need to understand the types of models being used, how these evolved and what the input. As to proxy data there are literally thousands of papers on e g. Pollen analysis from the Holocene to present day that are used to reconstruct the landscape. The Connolly's two papers looking at gasses in the troposphere are also excellent. 2014 I believe. Try Google scholar if you dont have access to research databases. Even archives of news paper reports in the 1920s and 30s are eye opening as they were experiencing higher temperatures and for extended periods, (unlike the odd day we have). In the USA literally 1000s died of heat and there was mass migration towards the coasts, same time of the dust bowls.

text:
I am for global warming (climate change) and reducing our dependence on fossil fuels. The fossil fuels are a limited resource and we don't know what will happen when they run out. I am also for nuclear power to be used and to always be a good fraction of our electricity. It is possible to run reactions on nuclear waste that can result in harmless isotopes at the end. Solar and wind need some kind of storage such as a battery to be viable. One such battery can be hydrogen electrolysis and fuel cells to store the electricity the comes from the sun and wind into hydrogen where the fuel cells can be run to provide electricity when no sun is shining and no wind is blowing. But the cost of "green new deal" should not be so high, in fact we have to invent so many new companies in the business to make it possible to lower the cost of alternative energy and make it usable, practical, and affordable.
Other kinds of power are biofuels, geothermal, tidal and wave, and more.

text:
@Karat Kravat  no it doesn't, as Tony Heller explains in many of his excellent videos.  If the earth is generally greening, then where are the droughts?  Further, why were there terrible world-wide droughts in the 30's when CO2 was relatively low by comparison.  Also, increased CO2 makes plants more drought resistant as it results in their stomata being smaller and open less often.  I live in a rural area of North America and this year was one wet year let me tell you.  Lots of snow last winter, and so much rain this summer I barely watered anything at all.  We've had a couple of feet of snow thus far in the fall, and it's still only October.  Correlation doesn't mean causation.  Royal Astronomical society predicts we're on the verge of another solar minimum according to the finding of solar physicist Valentina Zharkova ( https://electroverse.net/professor-valentina-zharkova-breaks-her-silence-and-confirms-super-grand-solar-minimum/).

You can stop worrying now!
author: Darwin Risdon

text: @Darwin Risdon  I know Tony Heller, I'm sure you've seen his debate with Peter Hadfield (Potholer54). I'm happy that we both follow People on the Internet who take part in scientific debates and talk about studies and how important fact checking is. So I'm asking you if you could state your sources about the Earth generally greening, the droughts in the 30's and the drought resistance of Plants with their stomata. I'll definitely read the source you cited about the solar minimum
author: Karat Kravat

text: @Karat Kravat  view any of the videos by Dr William Happer, Dr Willie Soon or Dr Patrick Moore.  They often cite the benefits of CO2 vis-a-vis drought resistance.  Tony Heller often cites historical records of climate alarmists extremes from a hundred or more years ago. Newspaper articles from around the world (in Tony's presentations) point to the fact that some extremes then were as bad or worse than now.
author: Darwin Risdon

text:
@Karat Kravat  watch this one by Dr. William Happer (professor emeritus, Princeton): https://youtu.be/U-9UlF8hkhs in which he explains the benefits of CO2 to plant growth.  I met with Dr. Happer at Princeton and he accommodated my visit most graciously.  He is a brilliant and very humble scientist, and a gift to science (Google his list of patents and scientific discoveries, not the least of which development of his "Guidestar" system for terrestrial telescopes).  

Most people don't know that CO2 is but 0.04% of the atmosphere, and human contributed CO2 is about 3% of that.  That makes the total anthropogenic atmospheric CO2 about 0.0012%!  Water vapor is hugely more influential than CO2, yet we are supposed to believe 0.0012% is responsible for destroying humanity.  Furthermore, it's effect is logarithmic, and it's very near its saturation point now (i.e. doubling it would have very little net effect due to the law of diminishing returns).  AND - lastly ... Vostok ice core samples from the Antarctic reveal that for about the past half million years, CO2 rise has always LAGGED temperature rise, it didn't LEAD it ...and the lag factor has always been  several hundred years.  Funny, then, how CO2 is the culprit! 🤔
author: Darwin Risdon

text:
Could you state the sources of your claims? CO2 was proven along side Methane and other green house gases to be the main driver in climate change. This can be observed by aiming a spectroscope (A device which splits light into waves and measures their intensity) towards the sky. Gases like CO2, Methane and Nitrogen will create a upwards curve (hill) with peaks on different wave lengths. The spaces which are free between these hills are where light can escape back into space. When CO2 and Methane increase, their hill/curve becomes wider, making that window smaller. That‘s one way to find out if CO2 affects climate change.

I don’t want you to believe me, please look up “scientific proof man made co2 affecting climate change” (with optional “scientif paper” or “university” at the end to find results of scientists and not blogs) and look at the result. Please, try to find out what the other side believes, look up their proof and try to understand what they say. It’s the best way you can defeat someones theory.

Find out what evidance they have, how they came to it and why they say it’s true. Finding evidence for the claims of the other side is the best way to find out why they’re wrong or why they’re right. Find the truth yourself

text: The problems with current renewable energy resources are two fold: one, efficiency, and two, environmental impact. Let's tackle efficiency first. When the environmental movement can provide me with a photovoltaic cell with an efficiency rating above 60% for a reasonable price, that will not bankrupt me to replace after ten years of use, then I will convert. When the energy companies have a product that would serve them better than fossil fuels, I won't have to switch because they will switch to it themselves. The wonderful thing about capitalism is that it drives innovation so companies produce more efficiently, including energy. Two, I seem to remember a group back in the day that wanted to build wind turbines offshore of Massachusetts and Ted Kennedy squashed that development because it would endanger local wildlife, and ruin his pristine waterfront views to his gold course. They like to wag their finger at me and mine, but aren't willing to change their own lifestyles to match their ideology. Why don't these "environmentalists" take the funds that they've collected, invest in research and development, and sell products that match their ideals? author: Alex Glemzu

text: Just had a Nor'easter blow through Maine last week.  Knocked out power to 200,000 homes.  They're still getting people up and running.  I lost power.  In 2017 we had one of these "bomb cyclones" come through as well.  It was twice as bad as this year's storm.  400,000 homes were without power in my state alone.  I didn't have power for a week.  The day after we had power restored - I went to Lowe's generator aisle - pointed at the biggest generac whole-home generator and said "I want that one!"  This time when the power was lost to the whole state - I lost power for all of 10 seconds.  My insulin stayed cool in my refridgerator for 3 days until we got power back.  When I first installed it, my crunchy neighbor told me that I should have installed solar panels like they had.  She said it powered their fridge and charged their cell phones.  My generator does that and so much more.  My wife was doing laundry while on generator power.  Also, my neighbor's solar panels got damaged in the storm last week and ended up not producing squat.  So thank you fossil fuels for being dependable, cost efficient, life-saving and accessible.

text:
Many YouTube channels are spreading disinformation and propaganda including PragerU,  GWPF, Tony Heller, Sky News Australia, Heartland Institute, Philosophical Investigations, and Friends of Science, among many others, and some are in the pockets of the fossil fuel interests.This video misrepresents facts and lies by omission.  Link:  https://www.ucsusa.org/our-work/global-warming/solutions/global-warming-solutions-fight-misinformation


It's true that the Earth's climate has been changing naturally in the past with hotter and colder periods and varying levels of CO2. That's stating the obvious. There are a number of factors that affect the climate including the sun's intensity, volcanoes, and greenhouse gases in the atmosphere, and any combination of these factors are in play at any given time. The climate scientists have ruled out the sun and volcanoes as factors in the current warming period. Natural changes in the climate occur very gradually, over thousands or millions of years. And while it's true that the global temp has risen only about 2 deg F in 100 years, this is about 170 times faster than in any past natural warming period. This video misrepresents all of these facts.


IMO, the most important topic the video fails to mention are carbon tax and cap-and-trade programs that allow for the continued use of fossil fuels, but at reduced carbon emission levels. These programs are have been successful in a number of countries and a few US states. But, of course the cost to the fossil fuel industry is significant, which is why they are fighting desperately against them, including by putting out bogus videos like this one.

text: Here's what's wrong with saying to someone: "look at yourself, you use tons of carbon yourself, why don't you practice what you preach?" How can he say that to her, when he himself is not willing to do it? And if she does do it, what then? It's disingenuous because it's not his real belief. If he believes climate change is a hoax, he should just say so. This is just a distraction, and a time-waster. If she says "Oh okay, yea you're right I should go change my ways!" Then what? Then will Piers Morgan agree that climate change is real? Is that the point? Or will he just say "Oh sorry I don't care, I still think it's a hoax." Why does she have to jump through that hoop to get an opinion from him? Either way, it's not relevant to the issue, which is do you think climate change should be addressed. It's simply a dodge from saying no I don't think it should be addressed. It's ad hominem, and it's illogical. Most of the greenhouse emissions are caused by a handful of companies, which is why we need change at the policy level. Which is why trying to shame someone who's helping to save the world from our stupidity is probably not going to help.

text: I feel like the info is kind of misleading when you show how CO2 makes up only .04 percent of the atmosphere. It makes it seem like it's completely insignificant. But when you add in the fact that 99 percent is oxygen and nitrogen which do not trap and absorb heat, it shows just how that .01 increase correlates to something a little more significant. And the source you provided shows how CO2 concentrations have increased dramatically within a 60 year period. 1700-1950 the concentration went from ~278 to ~315 ppm. 1960 to present ~409. It seems to be the highest and quickest increase in CO2 for the past 800,000 according to this source of course. I did not however check how accurate the testing methods were with the ice sheets. Do I believe that it could be a existential threat? Maybe. Do I think we are all going to die in 12 years. Hell no. I just felt that it was a little misleading and wanted to point that out.  If anyone would like to add to this, be my guest.

text:
There are a bunch of studies that have concluded that there is a link between carbon dioxide and global temperature.
Why? Why is it that they're still studying it? Isn't it known? Isn't it settled science?
No. See, pick up just about any two studies and they won't agree with each other as to what the link is. More than that, one will say something that makes the other impossible. And they'll pick different data that supports their arguments, because if you use the data of one study on another, the conclusions won't hold up.


This is how we know we are dealing with bad science. Results aren't reproducible, models don't fit any data beyond the study they came from, and their predictions of the future have always been wrong. We do not have a scientific theory that arises naturally out of the evidence. What we have is a narrative that people are trying to support with science despite the evidence.

text:
heres the thing that i disagree with, when it comes to debunking renewable energies:
you gain ENERGY INDEPENDENCE, when you use solar, wind or other generating form. think about it for a second, from a economic standpoint, if nearly every household in america (low desity houses and commercial buildings in this example) got off the grid, do you think we would need to power them anytime in the near future? less strain on the power grid too, if we think about it.
i hate government and what its done tho, BUT there does need to be sensible reform on a independent level.
the reason why most people aren't about to spend thousands of dollars on a home generation system, is not just because of the price tag, its also because of 2 very important things:
1. the left wants a national grid void of fossil fuels.
2. the right wants fossil fuels to power the national grid.


what if i told you, theres a more individual aspect to it? what if you can make your own hybrid wind/solar power system (solar for sunny days, and wind for stormy weather)? im not of either major political party, as i see both ignorant of the seriousness and scale of political corruption in this country, that drastic action is needed, however, why should the government be involved in anything energy, when we have the technology to make a change? think about this, what we need, isn't more regulation, or government control of the national power grid, that is already nationalized (like our water, roads, bridges, public schools and many other uilities we take for granted) and actually needs denationalization to bring in competition.
what we need is more research into renewables, not by the taxpayers either, people need to realize, we have the technology now to be completely off the grid. energy independence is around the corner if you spend that extra money.
think of it like this: you are investing in your own liberty to give big energy the middle finger!

How much land would that open up for fruit orchards and non-starchy vegetables?

What would happen if we stopped cooking with the highly toxic, high oxidized PUFA oils from seeds and soybeans and replaced that with butter and animal lard, stable and poorly oxidized saturated fat? 

What would happen if we only used seed oil and soy oil for biodiesel and machine lubricant? What if we gave farmers the legal right to make their own biodiesel from soy lard after they fertilize their fields with it via ferilizer crop? I imagine farmers with converted tractors for biodiesel would save enormous amounts on tractor fuel. text:
Transwarp: "the right wants fossil fuels to power the national grid."
No.  The right wants anything practical and cost effective to power the grid.  Nuclear is best, but lefties still have a lot of leftover fear based in ignorance to embrace it.  Besides, nuclear doesn't solve the fundamental motive--control of the people.

Transwarp: "... we have the technology now to be completely off the grid."
That would be good.  But how many people actually are?  If you're depending on solar, you need a big battery.  And if you have snow on your solar panels, you better get up there and clear them daily.  And if you have a windmill within a few miles of you house, it'll depress you.  (Watch the documentary on NetFlix.)

You almost certainly will want the option of connecting your home to the grid at some point.  And that requires government regulations to insure crappy voltage regulators don't bring the grid to its knees.

text:
Does dependance on a utility really increase our freedom though?  

All of these arguments presuppose that energy must always be a commodity that we purchase when renewables actually turn energy into something we can produce without any government interference.   

Solar and wind are nowhere near ready to replace fossil fuels,  but research and innovation in power storage have great potential.   New technologies in solar are making them increasingly inexpensive to produce,  and they are now less costly per KWh than coal.  

Not only does solar free you from government control and ineptitude,  like in the pg&e shutdown,  it also frees you from influence by other nations with large fossil fuel resources.   

As prageru's largest donor is a fossil fuel industry giant,  perhaps they have ulterior motives for wanting you to think solar is not ready.  

Maybe because they don't want you to buy some solar panels for the roof of your house and decrease your energy bill, increase your home's value, and become less dependent on them and the government.

@Majestic Stardust  how many choices do you have for electricity?  How about before  solar?  

Further how much choice do you have on when you get electricity?  Just a little bit ago pg&e shut down service to several counties, killing at least 1 person, to prevent fires.

Right now the way most people get electricity is without choice.  It is managed as a public utility, if you don't like it you have to move.  With solar you finally have a choice,  and a really good one, one that public utilities are also choosing,  because they are a good investment long term.  So you can choose to stay within the shackles while the utilities switch over to renewables,  which they will,  or start choosing which installers you want to use, which brands of consumer solar products you want, and then decide what you want to do with the power you make.

The trick that these two sides are playing is one for power, neither side wants to see you with more of it.

text:
I've got nothing against Alex Epstein, but he is grossly brushing over topics that don't belong together.

1st global greening is not thanks to more CO2 is because China and India are actively planting new trees.

2nd 0.03% and 1°C/2°F sounds very little yes, but my chemicals professor always said this: it's the dosage that makes the poison. So this little increase does have significant effects on the environment. The thing is, it's not like everything becomes warmer, rather, warm and dry years become hotter, humid areas become wetter, come areas become colder, etc. Basically the climate becomes more extreme. 
Anyone who understands how hurricanes and such things are formed will now understand that because of the more extreme climate hurricanes will happen more frequently. 

The melting of the ice caps is real. We have 2 ice sheets in the North. The North Pole and Greenland. The North Pole had somewhat recovered, but Greenland is now green. Which is a bag thing, because netto wise, we are still losing ice. 

3rd I am not saying climate change is man made. 

4th I do think we should try to do something about it, but what Greta Thunberg and the fff guys demand is just impossible. Impossible because of the political, scientific, industrial and economic mechanisms but also even if we were to skip the politics, those demands would disrupt our economy and society to a degree that a country can collapse from it.

text:
Fukushima's failure. According to a report dating March 2019 (8 years after) it's starting to get better, but the dangerous substances in the reactors won't be replaced/dealt with for many, many decades. The ambiant radioactivity levels close to the reactor are twice what you need to kill a man instantly. Even the robots they send in to film the situation have two hours of operation time before their wirings are destroyed by the radiations.

The releasing of progressively more substances into the oceans IS a problem that threatens the food industry at large. Consuming trace plastics and trace radioactivity is linked to a plethora of health issues, ranging from digestive issues to cancer.

I agree the Green New Deal's a scam. But Nuclear as a main focus? Not so quick to throw my cash in. In Quebec, 96% of our electricity comes from hydroelectricity, and our total energy production is enough to cover a third of Canada, approximately. I would rather have a 2-hour electricity failure once every 2-3 months than endanger the flora and fauna on which we feast by going full nuclear.

I invite civil discussion if you have reason to disagree, though!

It's far worse than you think. A recent discovery by two Irish scientists shows conclusively that greenhouse gases cannot produce warming. They figured this out by analyzing 20 billion data points from weather balloons, which have been in use for over a century.

You heard me right. The data they analyzed revealed that at all levels, the atmosphere behaves like an ideal gas, and an ideal gas cannot be warmed by greenhouse effects.. Only by direct forcing. That means 100% of the global average temperature is modulated by the sun.

Let us pray theycan get published.

text:
@Terry Tater  
Your claim of those 50 companies isn't a very good argument.   They may well emit all those emissions but the argument presented is that it isn't as big a threat than what is being advocated.   Citing wealth isn't an argument.....a consideration, yes,   but not an argument on whether we should be alarmed at those rates of emissions.   The type of argument that you're using sounds petty and envious.   Try using scientific data instead.   Data implies facts and the used of evidence.    If you want people to believe you,   do it the way the scientific method advocates instead of some backhanded allusion to "rich people bad".
author: Jack Haveman
Jack Haveman
Jack Haveman

text:
@Terry Tater  
Denigrating the intelligence of others is a sign of a weak argument.   
So many of us expect others to change but don't want to recognise that they have to change themselves as well.   That's his point.    She pointing fingers in every direction yet she is living the very lifestyle that she decries and she is a part of what sustains those industries.


If she wants changes in the world,  she has to be the example of what those changes should be.   Not live the good life on the status quo and then complaining how others are ruining it for all of us.
author: Jack Haveman

text:
@Terry Tater  
He isn't blaming her.   He's saying that we all have to change our ways to affect change and she won't address that.   Everyone has to change and it's not going be easy.


Polluting may not be a status thing but the accoutrements to status do pollute.    Why are so many still buying gas powered cars instead of electric cars?    Why are our homes so huge,  with rec rooms and added bars and bathrooms for every bedroom?  A TV in every room,   every electrical gadget imaginable?   Why do we insist that our lawns be immaculate and if it isn't we face fines?   Why the trips to the tropics in the winter and the weekend jaunts into the mountains or the cottage.   These are status symbols and a huge percentage of us in the west make it a part of our lifestyle.


Once again,  instead of blaming others,  why don't we look into ourselves and take responsibility for our own actions.   Everyone of those things I mentioned aren't necessary and I'm only touching the tip of the iceberg.   The average person won't even cut back 10 percent in their lifestyle.   That would be monstrous  and would be the impetus for a new economic base  that would be directed at this new way of living.   Nope.  Blame someone else as you turn up the air conditioner and watch a sporting event on your BIG screen TV and listen to the kid next door earn a few bucks by mowing your lawn on your new fancy riding lawn mower.  Don't forget the weed whipper.  Need one of those too.   


That's the life he's referring to.   You can't blame those 50 companies if the people insist of this as their lifestyle.
author: Jack Haveman

text:
@Terry Tater  
Being a country guy,  I can tell you how frustrating it is to see these city folk move into our neighbourhoods.   They come in and are surprised that the country isn't what they expected and then try to change it to the image they have in their heads....meaning, they try to change us.


Yes,  I'm conservative.   I'm about self reliance,  personal responsibility,  individual rights and sovereignty, hard work, and judging others on their character and integrity.   I don't decry the actions of others when I'm guilty of those things myself.   


I try to say what I mean and conversely,  mean what I say.   It's how people of integrity should try to live their lives.   I don't always succeed,  in fact,  I'm a failure a good part of the time but I recognise the weaknesses the reside in me.   That's why I take umbrage in the defensive stance of this woman.   She won't take responsibility for her part in what she sees as a problem.  She wants it to be about everyone else BUT her.   Had she admitted her role in this perceived problem and how difficult it will be to change the mindset of the average person,  the conversation could have went in a more positive direction.   But she wouldn't do that.   All she wanted to do was identify the bad guy and then exert control.


My ego isn't so grand that I think I can change the world but I do know that I can try to control my own actions.   Worse,  I don't have the right to control them anyway.   Change,  positive change, comes through a cultural renaissance,  led by consciences of  individuals,  acting on their own free will.  It's no different that the cultural change that the internet brought about.   Individual decisions to use the new technology,  no one being forced into it but a silent,  yet overwhelming force of personal choices.

text: I don't agree with the left's specific proposals for a more environment-friendly civilization. I don't agree with their deadlines, reported magnitudes or degrees of crisis, and etc. But I'll be damned if conservatives tell me our direction as a race isn't pointed towards the kind of world the left says we're eventually approaching. I'm sure it's not 12 years left but if animal and plant species go dying left and right, what do you think will happen to us humans? Established and fundamental scientific facts taught to us even as early as 9 or 10 yrs old about the importance of ecosystems and its balance say it all. Industrial sewage, plastics and other petrochemical products and byproducts cause indubitable damage and harm to various sectors of Earth life (thats another thing with PragerU vids, can we please stop ONLY talking about human this and human that. We depend more on animals and plants than they do humans). Don't get me wrong, I love PragerU. I strongly believe in PragerU's mission to educate the world on social science, history, economics, political science, good values, and simply being the best humans we possibly can to each other. But speaking in terms of other elements in our environment, natural resources, and the like, the long term of our species doesn't appear to be sunshine and rainbows. How PragerU skillfully rebuts the left's alarmist rhetoric to instantly take control of key industries of the world is a blessing because I too believe they're scary desperate megalomaniacal people masquerading as omnibenevolent government elites. I hope this sinks in even just a little. I acknowledge the immeasurable good fossil fuels have done for us all. But the reality is that it will have to be a balancing act, living on this planet. Not talking about the multitudes of species that have died out over the past 6 decades is just an out of sight, out of mind scenario. To make things worse, whenever you read things on the paper about dead whales filled with plastic, injured turtles, and highly developed nations illegally shipping their garbage in the tons to third world nations, you can't deny these are likely just a few of the many indicators signaling ecological crisis.

text: @Bishop  What? No, global warming has nothing to do with the toxicity of CO2. It's the effect of CO2 on global temperatures that is relevant way sooner than its toxicity. Also, our temperatures are pretty bad, they're increasing significantly faster than has ever been recorded, and by a large margin as well, and everything we know indicates it only gets worse as more CO2 is released. text: @The_Blazer  BTW the earth's atmosphere weighs 5.5 quadrillion tons. 4% of that is 220 trillion. So that's probably the correct amount to cause mass die offs. text: @The_Blazer  Sorry I was confused by your initial question. I thought you meant a bigger unit of energy. Big enough to see instant changes. Since 1 terawatt of solar energy = 85,000 barrels of oil. So the answer to your initial question would be. Nothing!
author: Bishop

text:
@Bishop  Oh well I didn't mean literally instantly, since we're talking about geological energy and petrol I thought it was clear that "all at once" refers to around 100 years as opposed to the 100 million years or so it takes for solar energy to slowly deposit as oil through fossilization. Also, obviously I'm not referring to abstract energy, but since we're talking about oil it's the equivalent CO2 emitted to regain the same energy from burning oil, hence why I said "combustion equivalent" and I did not refer to units of energy like joules.


Anyway I hope my super abridged explanation of how CO2 heats the atmosphere was decent enough. Obviously if we had a way to magically convert oil back into sunlight or electrical energy none of that would be an issue, but re-obtaining "stored" solar energy from oil necessarily requires burning it, so...

text: @Maxik  Gov't policy would be a cap and trade tax that makes energy companys pay tax for carbon emissions from the energy they sell to discourage use of the energy source by THE INDIVIDUAL consumer  (eg, gasoline).  The companys aren't going to just take a loss, they'll pass the tax along to the user.  It's still all about the individuals carbon footprint, whether it's reduced voluntarily or coerced by the gov't.  Got it?  It is a bit complicated.
author: ky le

text: @ky le   Okay. That specific policy is targeted at the corporations and their factories that produce those tonnes of CO2. It (at least in my state when it wad proposed 2 years ago) would apply to all companies and factories that produce a certain level of CO2. That is not a policy related to an individuals carbon footprint. It is about a company's carbon footprint. text:
Wrong Again: 50 Years of Failed Eco-pocalyptic Predictions

https://cei.org/blog/wrong-again-50-years-failed-eco-pocalyptic-predictions

SUMMARY
Modern doomsayers have been predicting climate and environmental disaster since the 1960s. They continue to do so today.
None of the apocalyptic predictions with due dates as of today have come true.
What follows is a collection of notably wild predictions from notable people in government and science.
More than merely spotlighting the failed predictions, this collection shows that the makers of failed apocalyptic predictions often are individuals holding respected positions in government and science.
While such predictions have been and continue to be enthusiastically reported by a media eager for sensational headlines, the failures are typically not revisited.
1967: ‘Dire famine by 1975.’

Source: Salt Lake Tribune, November 17, 1967
1969: ‘Everyone will disappear in a cloud of blue steam by 1989.’

Source: New York Times, August 10 1969
1970: Ice age by 2000

Source: Boston Globe, April 16, 1970
1970: ‘America subject to water rationing by 1974 and food rationing by 1980.’

text: I am not a fan of nuclear energy mainly because of the toxic waste it produces which is much more hazardous than the toxic wastes from burning fossil fuels and so requires extensive care in its safe segregation from the bio-sphere, for many, many years and thus problematic long term when considering possible breakdowns in containment of these wastes, perhaps due to natural disasters e.g. Fukushima.  A new discovery, requiring new physics to fully understand has recently been revealed and promises a better energy option in the future and incidentally may allow for the detoxification of nuclear waste.  Fusion energy has long been touted as the next great advancement in energy production but such efforts remain so far impossible and extremely expensive, until now.  The SAFIRE project has demonstrated the creation of heavier elements from lighter elements which normally would be called fusion, but because the process happens outside of accepted physical laws, the project team decided to use the term Transmutation rather than Fusion.  This feat was accomplished using very little power, something like 1800 Watts.  One must ask why this discovery is not worldwide news.  I don't have an answer to that question, but be assured that this very promising, paradigm changing research will be and is continuing and so bodes well for our future.  Here's a link to the project:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DTaXfbvGf8E

What he said at around 4:35 about "Unprecedented temperatures" sounds a bit sketchy to me. text: I don’t disagree with the video but it is missing a key aspect here...what about the developing/third world? Yes fossil fuels have done a lot of good and yes you can use it and engineering to combat any changes in the climate but what about places in the world that don’t have the western world’s resources? How should those people deal with changes in climate brought upon them by fossil fuels. I see a lot of people saying that we can sort out the problems with our technology until we have better fuel sources but what about the people that are almost completely dependent on the land, where there is corrupt/dysfunctional governments, where they are constantly struggling to survive? Small changes in the climate can have massive consequences for them. Should they just suck it up while the rest of the world sits in their air conditioned houses? That is the problem, countries and the people in them only see the problem from the perspective of how it will influence them, they ignore other more vulnerable countries - everyone (including vulnerable countries) contributes to the problem but not everyone will have to deal with the life or death consequences

author: Squidly
Brian Diehl

text:
@Brian Diehl  ​ - Ok then .. making some progress here .. we now have agreed that the atmosphere is partially heated by the IR emitted from the Earth's surface. And when I say "partially", I mean only a small percentage of the thermal energy of the atmosphere is a result IR radiation, the vast majority of the thermal energy obtained by the atmosphere is through direct contact with the surface through conduction. By the way, more than 72% of the Earth's surface is water, so the overwhelming majority of the thermal energy in Earth's atmosphere comes from conduction with the oceans on our planet, oceans that maintain more than a million times the thermal capacity of our atmosphere.

So, how does the CO2 in the atmosphere contribute to the FURTHER heating of the surface of our planet? .. remember, that IR originated FROM the SURFACE. How does this FURTHER heating of the surface, by CO2 and other so-called "greenhouse gases", occur? .. please be very precise and specific here .. as this goes to the crux of the entire "greenhouse effect" hypothesis.

As for your "you can measure in a jar" .. PROVE IT !!! .. nobody else has been able to .. perhaps you can do something nobody else has been able to do? .. I would really like to see this and I am sure I can gather another 20 or 30 million other individuals who would love to see it too. I'll wait...

Finally, do you know what an "oxymoron" is?

Oxymoron
[ˌäksəˈmôrˌän]

NOUN
An oxymoron (usual plural oxymorons, more rarely oxymora) is a rhetorical device that uses an ostensible self-contradiction to illustrate a rhetorical point or to reveal a paradox. A more general meaning of "contradiction in terms"

So, an example of an Oxymoron might actually be "the atmospheric greenhouse effect" (do you see the rhetorical paradox in that quote?)

text: @CK Lim  Yes, we did evolve around the equator, but first of all we never learned agriculture until we moved northwards to the midlatitudes where it is much easier, and we would have never had civilization had we stayed at the equator. If the productive regions of the world get too hot, that will hurt our ability to feed ourselves, and you can't just move agriculture completely into Canada overnight. Finally, while during our evolution, the equator was the ideal climate for humans with temperatures that required no clothing, the Earth is now on track to warm so much that large swaths of land around the equator will have their wet-bulb temperatures rise to lethally hot temperatures. Sure, you can use air conditioning, but you can't stay inside forever.

text:
@M S  No, John Tyndall was the scientist who described the link between CO2 and climate change. We can see a link in the geological records too. The thermodynamics of CO2 are reasonably well understood. 

Chemicals such as oxygen and nitrogen are paired in the atmosphere. 
Triple atoms bonded together atoms such as water, ozone, and carbon dioxide absorb infrared radiation from the ground and then radiate some of it back down to the ground or oceans. Thus causing the Earth to get warmer. 

As far as I'm concerned, yes climate change is a real phenomena and we should be doing something about it.

 I am also saying the climate change alarmists are guilty of child abuse and spreading propaganda. Those people are mostly politicians and environmental groups who want to use fear of catastrophic climate change as a means to raise taxes or funds. 
 
Even if CO2 did not warm the Earth, I still think it would be good for countries that can safely convert to nuclear power to do so.

In addition, to use the excess heat and electricity produced by the nuclear power station to produce methane via the Sabatier process and other technologies to convert that methane into petrol and kerosene.

author: M S

text:
@M S  that analogy is rubbish and irrelevant. No one in this thread is saying that carbon dioxide is causing the sun to shine brighter. 
 
The reason it was called the greenhouse effect was because it's an analogy! 
Greenhouses get and stay warmer due to several different types of phenomenon. 
The main analogy is that some types of glass are translucent to infrared radiation. 
 
Here is a lesson in English for you. 
An analogy must be comparable to the thing you are comparing it with. 
 
Here is a science lesson for you:
Heat is transmitted in three different ways. Convection, conduction, and radiation. 
So your first analogy would only apply to my argument if I was claiming that heat was being trapped by convection; I was not, I said some of the infrared radiation was absorbed or scattered, due to carbon dioxide being translucent to infrared. Just like a greenhouse glass is translucent to infrared radiation. 

However, a greenhouse also traps heat by preventing convection.

text:
@Digital Footballer  
I get it.  You hate paying attention,  so I guess I'll have to break it down for you.
He provided a claim in his comment.  This is called a hypothesis.  I pointed out the existence of its opposite, the claim that he's wrong , i.e., the bull hypothesis. 

If you cannot prove that the hypothesis is true, then we must conclude the null hypothesis is true instead. 

He refused to prove his claim (hypothesis), so we are left with only one plausible conclusion: the null hypothesis is true.

TL;DR, his inability to prove himself as correct is my proof that he's wrong.

Now, if you're done being wrong, mind providing something of worth to this conversation?

text:
This is long but PLEASE read these facts. I don't know whats worse...AOC, Bernie, Warren, Beto...so on, or the foolish ppl who've been duped into believing a false "theory" that ppl have anything to do with climate change, especially since the Obama's just spent $15 million on their new "oceanfront" forever home in Martha's Vineyard...hmm. You'd think by now ppl would realize that when the U.S. government pushes a narrative this hard its b/c its a $$$ maker; a false narrative: enter fake news/science. 


The worlds temp has risen, but its only up 1-2 degrees since 1970; but why has it risen, thats the Real question? People are NOT the ones contributing to climate change, and valid research is being silenced b/c theres no $$$ in it. If earth emitted "zero" Co2 emissions in the time politicians say we have left; AOC's 12 yrs to 2031, we'd see negligible results. Realize that todays "hard facts" are only politics and $$$. Its all purposeful "misinformation" and what we are being told is as far from the truth as the earth is from the sun; 93 mil miles; or just like these FACTS:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=17xh_VRrnMU&list=WL&index=2&t=0s   https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OwqIy8Ikv-c&list=WL&index=2


You've probably never heard of this person; a Danish scientist by the name of Bjorn Lomborg [in the above video and his most current findings in the link at the bottom of the paragraph], who a few years back wrote a very important book published by Cambridge. As you know Cambridge is very prestigious, and known for having people of the highest intellect. The book was titled "The Skeptical Environmentalist." Thats unheard of today. A scientist that wrote a book called The Skeptical Environmentalist. In it he debunked all the environmental positions b/c he KNEW it was based on "politics and lobbying" which led to $$$...lots of $$$, which then led to "pseudo and consensus science." He was vilified as a heretic by his peers, and the "Scientific American Journal" and he found himself on the outside looking in. If you've never heard about "consensus science" or a "consensus of scientists" let me enlighten you. First understand that it means there is NO EVIDENCE...no REAL proof b/c "consensus" is NOT science; thats why it took over. Also, it will sound something like: "A large group of scientists agree that"... Is this how science is done; by vote? TRUE science has nothing to do with consensus. Science requires investigators and researchers who've found "FACTS" via repetition, measurement, and observation. Consensus is irrelevant. If its consensus, its not science. Consensus is invoked only in situations where there is a political, social, or $$$ gain w/o scientific support, and climate change has created the [no pun intended], "perfect storm." No one ever says "the consensus of a large number of scientists is that E=MC square" or you'll never hear "the consensus of a large number of scientists is that the sun is 93 million miles from the earth"...statements like these are not made b/c they're FACTS. You don’t need a consensus b/c it has NOTHING to do with it. YOU DON'T VOTE ON FACTS. Did you know that there is absolutely NO extant "scientific" data [observable evidence] regarding Co2 or carbon, showing that mankind contributes to warming...NONE...its ALL merely theory i.e. "consensus science" which it has to be b/c its NOT; let me repeat; NOT evidenced via observation / science! Actually the opposite [scientifically] appears to be true, and this is what happens in layman’s terms. The sun gets hotter, and as it fluctuates, it gets hotter at certain times more than at other times, and when that happens it warms the oceans. As the oceans are warmed, THEY release more Co2 [which IS a scientific FACT, and has been for decades]. So, the sun determines the warming. The warming then effects the oceans, meaning that the oceans release more Co2 into the atmosphere. The "fact" then is this: Its NOT ppl putting Co2 into the atmosphere that warms the climate, its the sun that warms the climate, and the oceans are putting more Co2 in the atmosphere. ALL "honest" legitimate science shows that the human contribution to Co2 is barely negligible. Water vapor and clouds make up almost ALL Co2. text:
What you are describing is called an "ideal market" in economics, which is based on the following assumptions:

- everyone is honest about everything
- everyone has complete and flawless knowledge of everything in the market, such as residual oil levels
- everyone always acts in a perfectly rational way

In the real world, actual markets work more like this:

- companies routinely lie about everything, including residual oil levels
- people do not have either complete nor flawless knowledge, they are often not aware of the market consequences of what they're doing
- people do not always act rationally, for example, they might decide to continue using an outdated energy source because they're afraid that an objectively better energy source will somehow lead to communism

Besides this, what you are describing addresses oil shortages, not global warming. The issue with global warming isn't "when and while", but "how much". We know that the CURRENT amount of oil we have used is too much, by the time it runs out we'll be hurting real bad.

text: Henry Wylie ——Henry, I think you may be missing the point that was being made.  I’m certainly not a Piers Morgan fan, but every product he mentioned is engineered and/or produced with and by fossil fuels, and because they are produced with a cheap energy source, everyone CAN have them and take them for granted.  The anti-fossil-fuels folks seem to never stop and think what is truly produced with FFs—-of course gas, heating oil and electricity, but also majority of clothes, plastic, roads, etc etc.  Thinking that Elon Musk isn’t using fossil fuels to produce electric cars or that the electricity needed to run them can be made without a significant FF source, would be pure ignorance and just silly.  Without significant fossil fuels, we would very quickly cease to being a civilization, and I think that is the point.  According to the loudest voices in the climate-crisis rhetoric, the US “needs to be knocked down a peg” .  History has taught the enemies of the US that a frontal attack does little more than unite American citizens, kick the US industry into high gear, and solidify their resolve.  Because of the US and what its free markets have created in industrial and military power, the only real way to attack and destroy the US is from within, by removing part of the source of its power by over-regulation, excess taxation or social destruction....how it goes doesn’t really matter to them and they are hitting it from all sides.  Long-winded - sorry about that.

text:
Using small numbers is a really, really terrible argument.


If I take a piss in your bath, it will be mostly water, and 0.0014%ish will be of urea. Would you be happy with that ?


Or if you sit on a box of dynamite, I can exert 10 grams of pressure, equal to 0.00014% of your body weight on a switch. I suspect it would make a big difference to your life.

author: Chris Needham

text:
You are indisputably, 100% unambiguously wrong on this pal.
Climate change will definitely see the end of all human life on this planet, and nothing humans are capable of doing right now will stop it.
The argument is over whether it will be in as little as 100,000 years, or whether it will be 5-10 million.
And there's a further argument over how much of human's current activities are going to bring it toward the beginning of that range.
And then there's yet a further argument over how we handle the changes that will, definitely, occur over the next 100-200 years.
....Short answers are over-simplistic and retarded, and ignore a genuine problem.
